newsitem.title: USA: Cisco buys Telesend in stock swap.
newsitem.headline: Cisco buys Telesend in stock swap.

text.p: Cisco Systems Inc. said Wednesday it has acquired Silicon Valley start-up Telesend Inc., a maker of technology that allows phone companies to offer high-speed Internet access connections.
The acquisition, which was completed early this month in a stock swap, called for Cisco shares to be exchanged for all of Telesend's outstanding stock and options.

Cisco said the Cupertino, Calif.-based company's employees and management, including Sayuri Sharper, Telesend's president and chief executive, and the company's product line will be incorporated into Cisco's Wide Area Network business unit.
The company did not disclose additional terms and conditions of the acquisition of privately held Telesend.
Telesend has developed a telecommunications technology known as Integrated Services Digital Network Digital Subscriber Line, or IDSL for short.

The technology, which helps relieve congestion on telephone voice networks caused by rising Internet use, allows phone companies to offer Internet access connections from central office switches to local customers at speeds of up to 128,000 bits per second.
Cisco's stock was up $1.625 at $49.50 in early trading on the Nasdaq market.
